review.title: The Absent-Minded Driver Problem Redux
review.abstract: This paper reconsiders the problem of the absent-minded driver who must choose between alternatives with different payoff with imperfect recall and varying degrees of knowledge of the system. The classical absent-minded driver problem represents the case with limited information and it has bearing on the general area of communication and learning, social choice, mechanism design, auctions, theories of knowledge, belief, and rational agency. Within the framework of extensive games, this problem has applications to many artificial intelligence scenarios. It is obvious that the performance of the agent improves as information available increases. It is shown that a non-uniform assignment strategy for successive choices does better than a fixed probability strategy. We consider both classical and quantum approaches to the problem. We argue that the superior performance of quantum decisions with access to entanglement cannot be fairly compared to a classical algorithm. If the cognitive systems of agents are taken to have access to quantum resources, or have a quantum mechanical basis, then that can be leveraged into superior performance.

sections.text: Alternatives of varying utility with imperfect recall and varying levels of knowledge about the system. The classic, nonsensical driver problem presents the case with limited information and has implications for the general area of communication and learning, social choice, mechanical design, auctions, knowledge theories, faith and rational action. In the context of large-scale games, this problem applies to many artificial intelligence scenarios. It is obvious that the performance of the agent improves as the information available increases. It turns out that a non-uniform allocation strategy for successive decisions is better than a fixed probability strategy. We consider both classical and quantum mechanical approaches to the problem. We argue that the superior performance of quantum decisions with access to constraints cannot be fairly compared to a classical algorithm. If the cognitive systems are used by agents to have access to quantum resources, or have a quantum mechanical basis, then this can be used more efficiently.

sections.heading: INTRODUCTION
sections.text: The problem of rational choice with imperfect recall was introduced by Kuhn [1] and the matter of the absent-minded driver was investigated by Piccione and Rubenstein [2] as an individual game. Drivers must have a strategy to return home from different exit ramps that have different payout possibilities. The absent-minded driver has no memory and this represents a specific case of the problem concerning the choice between actions with state-dependent payouts. [3] Since the decisions made at different intersections do not depend on the previous one (due to the absence of the driver), this problem belongs to the class of decision-making with incomplete information and it has implications for the general area of rational agency, learning, the social choice of mechanism design, the auction theories of knowledge and belief. It is also of importance in such extensions of classical decision theory that involve quantum processes. Piccione and Rubenstein (PR) thought the situation will be slightly different to that of arriving at an intersection.
